div.p: Greetings and peace in... (the Lord) his.

To these letters of our Farellus, my father, I was going to add my own rather lengthy ones, which I wrote last week to you and to Mr. Martyr; but it happened conveniently yesterday that those letters of yours were returned to me, which you wrote to Mr. Calvin on the 13th of the previous month.

Since those letters discuss the whole matter much more fully, about which I had written to you, and I was not able to prepare a response so quickly, I am forced to delay, which I would have preferred to have done long ago. For I know the cunning of Satan.

But nevertheless, I promise myself the best of you and all ours there, to whom, as I hope, we are better known than for you to suspect anything wicked about us. I indeed hope to satisfy you in such a way that I will remove all doubt from you.

In the meantime, see, my father, that you love me; for certainly no obstacle will ever intervene that will break my respect for you and your entire church. I have already written to you familiarly about the four copies of the Bible sent to Mr. Zwingli; since Robert Estienne asked me for their price, I ask that, unless it is troublesome for you, you advise that the money can be safely entrusted to the one who delivers these letters to you. I also wish to inform Mr. Gesner that I have had for some time several copies of Athenagoras to be delivered to him, but I cannot find anyone to whom I can safely entrust them; for the opportunity of the Zurzach fairs passed me by while I was ill. See, my father, how familiarly I ask these things of you, and from this at least infer that I am and will be the same as I have been, namely, the one who wishes all things for your sake and expects all things in return from you.
Farewell, my father, with all your colleagues and fellow ministers, whom I certainly wish to be greeted most dutifully on my behalf. May the Lord Jesus bless you more and more.
Theodor Beza, most devoted to you in the Lord.
To the excellent servant of Christ, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the truly faithful pastor of the Zürich church.
